item.title: Parkinson Dragonboat and Multicultural Festival
item.description:
Forest Lake Parklands, Forest Lake
Ongoing through Thursday, June 6, 2013, 10am

The Parkinson Ward Multicultural and Dragon Boat Festival first held in 2010, is now an annual event on Brisbane's Multicultural calendar co-ordinated by the HAKKA Association, Forest Lake Rotary Club and the Queensland Dragonboat Federation and is proudly funded by the Brisbane City Council. 

As part of this festival, the day traditionally commences with a citizenship ceremony followed by a full program of multicultural entertainment, Dragonboat races with professional teams competing in the Lord Mayor's Dragonboat challenge and lots of multicultural stalls including a vast array of tantalising multicultural food. 

The Dragon Boat Festival commemorates the 2000 years' old story of the statesman and poet Chu Yuan, who in the 3rd century, in protest against a corrupt kingdom, threw himself into the Mi Lo River in despair.

Cost: Free
More info: www.angelaowentaylor.com.au…

item.title: Expect the unexpected - Market Street
item.description:
Market Street,
Brisbane
Friday, June 7, 2013, 5 – 9pm

Expect the unexpected.

Friday Night Laneways brings to life the hidden nooks and crannies of our city centre.  These spaces will be transformed through a vivid and captivating array of events, themes, performances and outdoor displays.

Market Street will be transformed with Jazz Vibes - a scintillating night of cool jazz, dance moves and good food. Featuring music from the internationally acclaimed Tyrone Noonan –as well as local jazz band SCAT.  Come on downtown and move to the groove.

Expect the unexpected.
Friday Night Laneways brings to life the hidden nooks and crannies of our city centre.  These spaces will be transformed through a vivid and captivating array of events, themes, performances and outdoor displays.
Market Street will be transformed with Jazz Vibes - a scintillating night of cool jazz, dance moves and good food. Featuring music from the internationally acclaimed Tyrone Noonan –as well as local jazz band SCAT.  Come on downtown and move to the groove.

item.title: Racecourse Road Winter Lights Carnival
item.description:
Racecourse Road
Ascot
Saturday, June 15, 2013, 3 – 9pm

The Racecourse Road Carnival was one of the first to be held in Brisbane and has a long and illustrious history. This year the Racecourse Road Winter Lights Carnival brings the local community together to celebrate Queensland’s amazing food and wine, fascinating local history and most importantly local creativity.

Cost: Family $20, general admission $5
More info: racecourseroadfestival.com.au…

item.title: Milton Community Festival
item.description:
10 Marie Street,
Milton
Sunday, June 16, 2013, 11am – 4pm

The Polish Association is organising a weekend of community activities involving local artists, multicultural folk dance groups, music and food.

We offer a free venue for the local and Brisbane artists to display their crafts.  This year is the 100 year anniversary of Polish Association in Queensland, so we will be adding historical displays and personal stories to show the cultural changes over this period.

Cost: Free
More info: www.polonia.org.au

item.title: Fête de la Musique
item.description:
Various venues across Brisbane
Friday, June 21, 2013, 5:30am – 8pm

Music lovers are in for a treat as the city gets ready for a sound explosion!

Brisbane will join the global community as musicians young to old, from all backgrounds, genres and abilities, take part in the largest International live musical celebration in the world - Fête de la Musique!

Watch out as street corners, cafes, workplaces, schools and even public transport become a stage across the city.

Developed by the French Government in 1982, Fête De La Musique is today celebrated in over 450 cities worldwide with the main aim to make music everywhere and to expose as many people to music as possible on the very same day each year – 21 June.

Keep an eye out for this delightful and spontaneous musical affair.

www.fetedelamusiquebrisbane.com.au

Presented by Brisbane City Council in partnership with Brisbane Marketing and Alliance Francaise

Cost: Free
More info: www.fetedelamusiquebrisbane.qld.gov.au
item.xCal:description:
Music lovers are in for a treat as the city gets ready for a sound explosion!
Brisbane will join the global community as musicians young to old, from all backgrounds, genres and abilities, take part in the largest International live musical celebration in the world - Fête de la Musique!
Watch out as street corners, cafes, workplaces, schools and even public transport become a stage across the city.
Developed by the French Government in 1982, Fête De La Musique is today celebrated in over 450 cities worldwide with the main aim to make music everywhere and to expose as many people to music as possible on the very same day each year – 21 June.
Keep an eye out for this delightful and spontaneous musical affair.
www.fetedelamusiquebrisbane.com.au
Presented by Brisbane City Council in partnership with Brisbane Marketing and Alliance Francaise

item.title: Suburban Networking Marketplaces
item.description:
St Augustine's Church,
Racecourse Road,
Hamilton
Saturday, June 22, 2013, 9am – 2pm

Suburban Networking Marketplaces highlight the imagination of Brisbane's creative communities. Over tea and bikkies meet representatives from local craft groups and guilds, and mingle with emerging indie crafters in an old fashion suburban marketplace environment.

With marketplaces at the four points of the compass, each will include presentations by inspirational speakers from the local area, who will analyse and discuss thei own creative journey. Traditionally marketplaces encourage and enhance social inclusion and participation. These will showcase local craft work and provide knowledge and resources within Brisbane's neighbourhood craft communities.

Cost: Free
item.xCal:location: St Augustine's Church, Racecourse Road, Hamilton
item.xCal:description:
Suburban Networking Marketplaces highlight the imagination of Brisbane's creative communities. Over tea and bikkies meet representatives from local craft groups and guilds, and mingle with emerging indie crafters in an old fashion suburban marketplace environment.
With marketplaces at the four points of the compass, each will include presentations by inspirational speakers from the local area, who will analyse and discuss thei own creative journey. Traditionally marketplaces encourage and enhance social inclusion and participation. These will showcase local craft work and provide knowledge and resources within Brisbane's neighbourhood craft communities.

item.title: World Refugee Day Community Festival
item.description:
Annerley Soccer Club Fields,
Victoria Terrace, Greenslopes
Sunday, June 23, 2013, 9am – 5pm

Celebrate cultural diversity and vibrancy with refugee communities.

Australia’s largest refugee festival comes alive with colourful, energetic and engaging music, song, costume and dance, visual arts and craft exhibitions.

A great family event where you can sample delicious foods from around the world and learn how to create them.

Presented by Brisbane City Council in association with Multicultural
Development Association

Cost: Free
More info: www.mdainc.org.au
item.xCal:location: Annerley Soccer Club Fields, Victoria Terrace, Greenslopes

item.title: Games Night
item.description:
Thursday, June 27, 2013, 5 – 8pm

Start the weekend early by playing board games on Thursday night with your friends in Reddacliff Place.

Whether on your own or with your buddies, a novice or a pro, battle
it out with chess, Chinese checkers and many other classic board
games night games.

Just remember it’s not about whether you win or lose – it’s how you play the game.

Venue: Reddacliff Place
Venue address: 266 George St, Brisbane

item.title: Teneriffe Festival
item.description:
Vernon Tce, Teneriffe
Saturday, July 6, 2013, 10am – 10pm

The Teneriffe Festival was conceived after Brisbane’s inner city area of Teneriffe was officially named a suburb, early in 2010. 2013 marks the fourth year for the Teneriffe

Festival, in which we will celebrate the suburb’s history, energy, cultural diversity, commerce and beauty. The Festival incorporates a rich program of events, from street markets, concerts and historical displays. Several of Teneriffe’s main streets will be closed, offering our visitors a magnificent opportunity to discover the best that our suburb has to offer.

The Teneriffe Festival attracts an audience of approximately 30,000 people across all of its events, making it one of Brisbane’s most significant new festivals.

Cost: Free
More info: www.teneriffefestival.org

The Teneriffe Festival attracts an audience of approximately 30,000 people across all of its events, making it one of Brisbane’s most significant new festivals.
